item.title: Hard lessons in leadership
item.description:
This is what consistently got me into trouble in my career.

Sticking my nose where it doesn't belong.

Let me explain.

I'm not good at following orders and sticking to my box. I never have been.

If I see a problem, I will solve it. What gets me into conflict is that the core problem is usually not mine, but its effects are.

Like a product team pushing a bad feature.
Or marketing opening the floodgates without a heads-up.
Or sales promising something that the tech team can't commit to.

Two more things are going against me: I love learning new things, and I'm confident.

So, if someone's not doing their job properly, guess who's taking it?

I am.

If you're a bit like me, you'll have a hard time winning like that.

You'll eventually push everyone around you out of a job.
You'll have way too much work on your hands.
You'll probably get many things wrong.

Learning that pushover leadership does not yield results took a long time.

Boundaries.

This was the toughest nut to crack. Before you can enforce your boundaries, you must know what they are.

But for that, you need to define your role (for yourself).

Not every problem is yours to solve.

That doesn't mean doing nothing.

It means that you need to go to the source and tell John to fix his shit because it's wreaking havoc downstream.

Guide, don't take over.

You can either fix it yourself or guide someone else to do it.

If you guide, it will take longer. It will suck watching them stumble.

But it's also the only way they will learn.

Be strategic.

You can't fix everything, so focus on the things that can bring the most positive impact.

Use influence to nudge things in the right direction instead of taking direct control.

If everyone else is an idiot.

You're either in a bad company, or it might be you. In either case, a role change will resolve either of those problems.

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: Less is more
item.description:
Features are expensive to build, hard to maintain, and don't necessarily produce meaningful user value.

When has quantity over quality led to an outstanding user experience?

I like Dieter Rams' design principles, which Apple took great inspiration from.*

Weniger, aber besser — less, but better.

The real question is not how much you can add. It's how much you can take away.

That's true for products and processes.

Less is more.

Best regards,

Taj

*Ten Principles of Good Design by Dieter Rams

item.title: Going freelance
item.description:
Is like climbing a rock, blindfolded without a rope with snakes on the ground to soften your fall.

I've tried it several times in my career, but it sounded better in theory than practice.

In theory, you've got all the time in the world. You work on exciting things. You can choose your projects. And you are your boss.

In practice, declaring yourself a freelancer and changing your job on LinkedIn to "Self-Employed" does not make you rich.

You stare at an empty calendar and wonder what to work on.

The problem is that there are unlimited options, but only a few will move your business forward.

The rest? Just busywork.

In a typical 9-5, busy work is paid as much as strategic or other work, even playing Mario Kart.

You get your salary.

When you are freelance, busy work = 0. Sick days = 0. Vacation = 0.

Unless you've built a hands-off service, but for most of us who get paid for solving problems, that's downtime.

It gets worse. Your signals for what's working come with one hell of a delay.

But it has an incredible upside:

What you get paid directly correlates to the value you create. *

If you solve bigger problems, you can command a higher rate.

This is not how most jobs work.

In a job, what you work on is typically completely disconnected from its impact on the business.

If more companies bridged the two, more people would feel purpose in a 9-5 job.

No one wants to be just a cog in the machine.

Best regards,

Taj

*and how well you can demonstrate that value

item.title: My beef with morning standup 🥩
item.description:
Mornings are the premium part of the day for many people.

You wake up, get coffee, and you are fired up to tackle the most important problem of the day (provided that you're working in an environment where you give a damn).

Instead, you check your email and keep busy on Slack because there's a scheduled interruption at 9.30, and it's not worth loading your brain up with "the problem space" for just over an hour of progress.

You'd want at least three because it takes an hour just to get into the zone.

So you wait for your biggest chunk of uninterrupted time to do that. And it will probably be at night when Slack is quiet and your kids are asleep.

The thing is ...

Alignment is important, but it can be done:

  • In the afternoon, as a quick summary of the progress you made and any blockers for tomorrow
  • Async

So, if you're overloading your team with countless planning meetings, please approve my code requests and "strategy" meetings:

It's time to rethink that approach because it's probably killing a lot of gains.

The trouble is, you can't just kill the daily and expect great results.

You need a bit of passion, plenty of independence, a sense of ownership, and a clear trajectory.

A team like that will walk circles around a competitor who worships busyness and expects its members to put in 8 hours of "programming."

P.S. What are your thoughts on developer productivity? Lemme know by writing a short reply. I read them all. ♥️

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: The 3 minute demo
item.description:
Here's a suggestion that has proven to work well for me and my teams:

At the end of the day, as you wrap up, record a short demo of what you accomplished and share it with the team.

Add any blockers or important information they need for a great start the next day.

Free ways to do it:​
QuickTime Player, OBS Studio

Paid services:

Loom, ClickUp, ScreenRec, Wistia, Sendspark, Vidyard, ScreenFlow ...

It's especially useful for remote-only teams, but even in an office, checking only the updates you're interested in at your pace, can save everyone time.

A few considerations before you implement:

  • Not everyone is comfortable in front of the camera, but a screen-only recording works just as well.
  • It's a skill to learn but does not need to be complicated.
  • It may put on the pressure to prepare something you can show instead of doing deep work.

On second thought, have you ever had someone on the daily trying to come up with what they were supposedly "working on" yesterday but have nothing to show?

Yeah, the format of the update is not the problem.

P.S. François sent me a reply yesterday saying that he kept this up after our project, and it also works well for his other freelance projects. 👌🏻

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: Product 🥊 Tech
item.description:
This is what a product-driven organization looks like:

And I have yet to see one that does this effectively.

The idea is, that you have a strong product department that figures out the customers' needs, what features need to be built, and how they should look like.

The tech team then builds those features and ships them to the users.

The trouble is...

Every time I've seen this in practice it ended up with waterfall and silos.

Here are a few issues:

  • The product involves tech too late in the planning stage, without knowing the impact of a feature.
  • Lots of information is lost when passed through JIRA tickets from one department to another.
  • Tech is seen as just an execution engine, not a driver of innovation.
  • Product pushes too many features into execution, straining the dev team who then becomes defensive.

Progress stalls.

It's made worse by a lack of ownership and accountability. When things are passed between the teams, it's easy to blame the "other team".

We built it to spec, it's your assumptions that were wrong!

Until everyone is pointing a gun at everyone else.

The thing is ...

Sometimes I get asked by someone who wants help and describes the above organizational structure why any feature they want to ship is met with resentment and is a damn effort to get to production.

It's because you designed your organizational structure for friction not flow.

If you want to succeed, it's much better to have small cross-functional teams that are responsible for a chunk of the app.

You'll want to have shared goals that drive the business forward.

You'll want a tech team that feels encouraged to contribute solutions instead of working "to spec".

And you'll want transparency so that everyone feels they are a part of the same mission.

The next time I walk into this kind of organization, I'm smashing my sledgehammer against the org chart and we're rebuilding with the reverse-Conway maneuver as described in Team Topologies.

With flow, accountability, and ownership in mind.

P.S. Has this setup ever worked for you? Please prove me wrong, I'd love to get a counter-example.

Best regards,

Taj

​

item.title: The puppet CTO
item.description:
...has all the blame with none of the authority.

And most small and medium companies get this wrong.

The Chief Technology Officer is a strategic and executive role.

However, in most organizations, the role lacks executive power and is rarely strategic.

At best, you're the most experienced engineer, a technical team lead, or a software architect.

At worst, you're holding the master AWS login, assigning JIRA access, and fixing tech stuff that breaks, like MS Teams, for your non-technical coworkers.

But...

Can you hire a freelance DevOps engineer without approval?

Do you have access to a company credit card to try out a SaaS?

Can you fire a bad hire without weeks of company-wide negotiation?

Yeah...

If the answer is no, you've found yourself in the puppet CTO role.

It's pretty easy. Let's look at one of the job ads advertising a CTO role:

You will handle:

  • Technical Leadership
  • Team Management
  • Architecture & Design
  • Hands-on Development
  • Decision Making

The thing is...

This is a catch-all role, and someone who finds themselves in it will likely spend most of their time writing code, fixing bugs, managing JIRA issues, and feeling overwhelmed.

The leadership thinks they're saving money by getting someone who can do everything, including code development, IT, software architecture, and hands-on team management.

Some people who step into the role can redefine it, slowly take ownership, and hand over the tactical things to their team to focus on the strategy, but plenty can only with help.

There's no one answer that works for everything. Many of the problems stem from the changing requirements of the role as the company scales.

It will be way different with 3 engineers and 100.

But the decisions you make at the start, could influence the entire trajectory of the company.

So, a company without a strategic and executive technical leader is betting on luck to make the right choices.

And luck is not a method.

...

If you're applying for a puppet CTO position, it's important to address the limitations and present that you can't do your best work without executive power and the space for strategic thinking.

Redefine a role you'll be comfortable stepping into.

If you're a company that has a puppet CTO, it's time to think about how you can relieve some of his responsibilities so that they can evolve into a strategic executive role.

And get them the help they need.

P.S. What's your take on the puppet CTO role?

Best regards,

Taj Pelc

item.title: Add learning from failure
item.description:
You'll learn much faster if you can leverage both sides an experience can offer.

Imagine you're at a company and notice something working exceptionally well.

By studying this success intensely and understanding why it works, you can replicate it the next time.

Nice.

Now, imagine the opposite. Let's say you come to a place with a lot of dysfunction. Things don't work at all.

Perfect!

It means you get to play detective. You study the situation. Find the reasons for it—research potential fixes.

In the best case, you implement them and fix the problem(s).

In the worst case, your solutions get rejected, and you try again at a different company.

From my experience, there's way more dysfunction than excellence.

If you only learn from the positives, you leave most of the growth on the table.

P.S. How much of your lessons learned come from "I've seen how not to do it"?

P.P.S. The inverse of how not to do it is probably not how to do it. But you've eliminated one bad way and are one step closer to the solution. Sometimes a big step.

Enjoy the rest of the weekend,

Taj

item.title: No, send me your boss instead
item.description:
As the CTO, almost everyone in the company will want to put something on your plate.

Strategic decision-making is key. If you said yes to every request, you'd overwhelm yourself and your team in 5 minutes.

If you say no to opportunities that would significantly impact the business's bottom line, you're doing the company a disservice.

It's a tricky balance.

You choose by figuring out the impact.

Plenty of times, a request comes by proxy.

The one who is asking for something doesn't know the impact. They are just playing telephone.

Here's what I've found out...

You'll want to weed out requests like that.

Ask for the outcome.

If you smell it's not their accountability, ask them to send their boss instead.

If they don't own either the budget or the result, it's pointless to negotiate.

P.S. And don't fix their printer either, politely. 😅

Have a fantastic start to next week,

Taj

item.title: Mastering office politics
item.description:
You know how people say, "I avoid politics at work".

That strategy may work when you're a grunt.

But in a leadership position, you're one of the elected officials. There's no avoiding the politics.

What you do instead is develop a strong spider sense of who is campaigning for what.

Learn the power dynamics.

If you want to make real changes to the way things are done (because you have a vision for something better), you can't do it alone.

You need to get other people on board.

That means finding allies, drumming up support, and winning people over.

You can't avoid politics.

But you can choose how you'll play.

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: Why I email daily
item.description:
I got a question recently from someone who wants to get into writing a newsletter.

Why daily?

For me, it's all about building a consistent habit. If I have to do it daily, it's like brushing my teeth.

I've been emailing for 70 days in a row. Haven't skipped a day.

I started enjoying my new evening routine—just me, you, and a thought that gets expanded into the newsletter.

Benefits

I've done many repetitions, and it's getting easier to write.

I got great feedback from many of you. Honestly, I was expecting people to throw in the towel after a few emails, but most of the people I contacted personally stayed.

I also created 70 pieces of content from ideas that used to be floating around my mind, which I plan to turn into other formats, such as long-form articles or videos.

What to improve

I've built a consistent practice. Now, it's time to let people know that it exists.

There's a step to add to start consistently cross-posting to X and LinkedIn so that new and organic audience has the chance to see it.

Secondly, I'll create a few freebies by bundling common themes I've explored into an email sequence like a short course.

And with the daily email, after this experimental first period, I'm sticking with it. Let's go for a year.

P.S. Thank you for sticking around. It means the world ♥️.

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: Simple beats fancy 🎩
item.description:
When starting a new software project, you may feel tempted to try a new framework or a different stack.

Bite your lips and don't. 🚫

If I had a cent for every time I had to work in an obscure framework for a subsystem because the first developer had free reigns, I'd have one ice cream.

The thing is ...

At the start, you want to build fast and adjust. Optimize for learning.

In an ideal world, you'd throw away the prototype and build it properly.

In the world we have prototypes become the products.

Make informed tech choices from the start:

  • Choose boring tech that's been proven to work.
    (and you have plenty of experience in)
  • Something that you won't have trouble hiring for.
  • That makes the stack easy to learn and fast to develop.

Simple beats fancy.

Proven beats experimental.

Bonus: Use the foundations that someone else made for you. Don't write your own Docker Composer; use docker-compose.

P.S. What's your boring stack of choice?

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: The Strangler Fig
item.description:
Instead of trying to rewrite a legacy system, the strangler fig is a gradual process of modernization.

You write small additions on top of, but separate of the new codebase.

Martin Fowler came up with the name and I've just read his updated article on the topic.

When I tried this approach on a project late last year, I got some things right, but some things wrong.

There are four key activities for this kind of approach:

  1. Understand the outcomes you want to achieve
  2. Decide how to break the problem up into smaller parts
  3. Successfully deliver the parts
  4. Change the organization to allow this to happen on an ongoing basis

Number 2 is tricky. Figuring out the seams of a legacy system can sometimes feel like untangling overcooked spaghetti.

My mistake was not diving deep enough into the code, early enough to not just define a strategy, but also the tactic.

How do we slice it and where.

Once I did that, things started to flow. I found how to replace the "engine" of the app, but kept the interface the same.

In total, it's more work. It gets complicated with feature flags.

But this approach will de-risk the transition and you'll get value out of the modernization sooner.

Here's the full article: https://martinfowler.com/bliki/StranglerFigApplication.html​

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: Teams who care produce better products, faster
item.description:
The best teams are close to the customers.

They can see the results of their work.

They are involved in the business.

Those teams have coincidentally also been the most fun to work in.

Building a tech product is good, but solving a real problem for someone is better.

People who care about the work they do will do a better job at it.

Find ways for the engineers to care about more than just the framework and the architecture.

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: The 🚌 Factor
item.description:
The smallest unit is the team, not the individual.
​
In a small team, this tends to happen. One person is in charge of a part of the system.
​
Bob is the only developer implementing payment providers.
Alice supports marketing and builds landing pages.
Jane does all the deployment scripts.
Fred maintains the admin interface.
​
This is the typical setup.
​
We can't deploy when Jane is sick, and no landing pages get tweaked for two weeks when Alice is on vacation. And let's hope Bob doesn't quit even though he's burned out.
​
Bus Factor: 🚌🔥 (1)
​
This is a terrible situation. The system only works when everyone is at work and has an equal load. That rarely happens in the real world.
​
Let's say we need to build more landing pages. I guess Alice is working overtime this weekend without any help.
​
How to fix this?
↳ Transfer the ownership of subsystems to the team.
↳ Cross-train people to be able to work on more subsystems.
↳ Instead of assigning, let people pick and choose tasks (pull vs push).
​
Here is what we did with a CTO that I was mentoring.
​
We created an on-duty system where, during standard working hours, a pair of engineers would first clear all the reactive tasks—customer support requests, bugs, etc. 🫡
​
Those would inevitably touch different systems, forcing the engineering pair to learn how to work with, update, and deploy that system. The people with the best knowledge of that subsystem would support it.
​
In a few months of this rotation, every team member had at least a surface-level understanding of all the subsystems.
↳ The knowledge in the team increased.
↳ The team is more independent (they don't need to be instructed on how to fix something).
↳ The bus factor is no longer a problem. It's a bus fleet. 🚍🚍🚍
​
Ultimately, we could cancel the on-duty system as it achieved the desired result.
↳ Productivity went up.
↳ People can help each other out.
↳ Vacation and sick leave is possible.
↳ Working on an actual team instead of a collection of soloists is more fun.
​
That's the good stuff that I like to see.

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: Bad hire
item.description:
A bad hire can set you back for weeks or months when building a tech team.

I'd rather suffer a few more weeks without that person than fill a position with someone who's just ok.

The difference between a "person" and "the right person" is not a few percent.

It's likely the difference between success and failure.

Set a high bar. Choose wisely.

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: Fewer things of higher value
item.description:
Focusing on strategic work is hard when everything around you is on fire.

In a leadership role, everything is on fire by default.

But not all fires are equal.

Some are legitimately bad and require attention.

Some you can let burn without ill effects.

Some you leave on others to fight.

The thing is ...

It's hard to focus on the strategy when you're in the thick of it.

For me, it works best when I'm in a productivity sweet spot.

Busy, but not overworked.

Don't aim to take everything from your plate to focus on strategy.

Make enough space for a few weekly sessions to allow for strategic work.

I like Cal Newport's approach of having a long-term strategic plan that gradually becomes a weekly and daily plan.

With regular check-ins on the activities that go on in the tech team.

Then do less. Prune.

Be curious about every in-progress initiative and ask:

How does this translate into business outcomes?

If there's no clear answer, eliminate it.

Work on fewer things of higher value.

P.S. The other extreme of having an empty calendar is even worse for strategic work. You may crave an empty calendar, but be careful what you wish for. An empty calendar is only good for taking a vacation.

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: Scaling from a low-code MVP
item.description:
Following a successful investment, a startup founder, who initially developed their MVP using a low-code/no-code platform, has outlined a plan they have to rebuild it in-house.

While functional, the current solution (already on the market in 11 countries) presents an exciting opportunity for growth but requires an unsustainable amount of manual labor to keep the product working.

So they are hiring the first in-house technical hire (tech lead) to build the tech team, set up the foundation, architecture, and strategy, and work on it hands-on.

I won't deconstruct that job description today; I want to focus on what it means to transition to building software from the ground up (including the team).

Here's the thing ...

Building it custom is not just a tech upgrade; it's a strategic move.

You'll need to choose a sound technical foundation.

You'll need to plan how to build and grow the team.

You'll need to identify which parts of the existing MVP to custom-build first so that they start generating value as soon as possible.

It's a significant investment in time, effort, and money, so the upside of the change needs to be massive.

Here's the plan ...

Use a hybrid approach; start by building out the part of the system that solves a concrete problem and has a clear benefit.

Get to production fast with it. Start the learning loop.

Iterate and expand, custom-building more of the overall system.

Define goals in terms of outcomes, not features.

Here are a few pitfalls to avoid.

Overengineering
​Don't replace parts that don't need to be replaced, and use boring technology.

Isolation
​Keep the tech team from building in isolation. Quick deployments. Cross-functional teams. User-centric.

Unrealistic expectations
​Be honest about timelines and outcomes. It will be more expensive and take longer than you think, especially if you have a side project of building an amazing engineering team from zero while rebuilding the product.

Neglecting the cultural shift
​This will impact all other departments and how they function. The company will need to adapt. Plan for it.

One final thing ...

Mistakes at the start of such a project can be costly because many decisions that need to be made are non-reversible or hard to reverse.

Once you build a few services in Java, you cannot switch to Go if that proves to be a better choice for the type of project you're building.

Be careful about going in without a plan, but don't only depend on a plan. As you go on, knowledge increases. Lean on principles and stay flexible.

Best regards,
Taj

item.title: The do-it-all tech lead
item.description:
You can't efficiently build a tech team, set foundations, develop software architecture and tech strategy, work on the code, and create the infrastructure simultaneously.

Something's gonna give depending on where you focus the most of your energy.

Spend too much on building the product, and you'll have a weak team.

For context, if you want to build a tech team of 6 from scratch*:

CVs to screen: 500 - 1000​
Interviews to conduct: 50-80​
Offers to extend: 7-9

You can expect to spend 100 - 245 hours just on the hiring process alone.

Plus, you need to onboard them and give them the support they need to become productive team members.

Sure, you'll probably have other people helping, but each responsibility you take takes a chunk of your brainpower.

Yet, many companies who want to start from scratch are looking for the unicorn who can do it all.

The thing is...

You don't start with code.

You start top-down with the business requirements.

That drives your high-level strategy → tactics → daily actions.

Focus is important.

And focus is about deliberately saying no to things you want to do.

Perhaps, like me, you enjoy writing deployment scripts but decide not to do it yourself because a solid hiring process will give you a better impact.

Get someone better than you, faster, and let them write deployment scripts.

Business is not a sprint; it's a marathon.

Don't throw away long-term impact for short-term gains (unless you have a damn good reason).

P.S. I'm not saying one man can't design, architect, code, and deploy a product. Those exist. I'm saying it's damn near impossible to do that AND build a performant team in parallel.

Best regards,

Taj

*based on industry average conversion rates

item.title: Is AI taking programmer jobs
item.description:
I've recently seen people impressed by Claude's ability to create a functional React app with a simple prompt.

Cool? Very.

Useful? Perhaps.

The "app" was a simple widget with sliders to split a bill.

While impressive, the difference between widgets and production apps is massive.

The thing is ...

I've been using Claude Sonnet 3.5 for the last few months, and I love the ability to create a project, upload context, and set a custom prompt to instruct it how to react, and have it persist across conversations.

As a large language model (LLM), it's amazing at generating (code, text) from a prompt.

But if you want to use it to build something useful, you must know what you're doing.

If you use it a lot, the articulated way it can express itself makes you think it's got the smarts.

But after a while, you realize that it's not intelligent.

It can't make decisions.

If you take the same prompt and the same context and try multiple times, the results will deviate.

So yes, it's an amazing tool.

But you need to know how to use it. It can make you faster, and it's great for prototyping.

Just don't expect it to be Jarvis from the Iron Man.

We're still well off that mark.

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: Quick question
item.description:
What product, service, or technology are you currently using that you absolutely love?

It can be anything from a screenshotting app to a web framework, SaaS ...

I'm trying to learn about some cool stuff that flew below my radar.

Hit reply and let me know.

Thanks!

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: Start small, grow big
item.description:
Becoming a strategic leader means shifting most of your priorities.

This is hard because writing code and deployment scripts is familiar.

You're good at it.

You had years to practice.

Focusing on strategy is new.

You're a beginner again.

And being a beginner sucks.

So, shift gradually and don't take off your plate everything you enjoy.

That's a sure way into trouble.

Instead, start with a few solid blocks of high-impact strategic work per week and build up from there as you improve.

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: Just fix the build process
item.description:
It's high time we address the surprisingly poor developer experience at many companies.

The devs are just suffering through the long manual build times.

Or the dev environment is so complex to set up that it takes months to get the thing just right.

And then a new hire breaks his teeth on trying to set everything up.

It's painful every time I land on such a project.

And you know what it often takes?

No more than a day or two of pimping out the build process and the tooling.

You just need someone who's bothered enough to do something about it.

Are you done manually assembling dev dependencies?

Good. You have my permission to fix it. ;)

Best regards,

Taj

​

item.title: Who the hell coded this piece of 💩!
item.description:
One of the best things I've done that improved my tech team performance is to foster a sense of shared ownership in the team.

It's not "the companies'" code base.

It's my codebase. And it's your codebase.

And if it sucks, there's no blaming the guys that built it (badly, drunk, 10 years ago).

It's on me and you.

If it sucks, we fix it until it stops sucking.

Simple mindset change, but it makes all the difference.

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: The smart way to get results 💡
item.description:
I was never the best at writing code.

However, I always had an innate ability to see code as a solution to a business problem.

I'm also lazy, so I don't like to do work that doesn't contribute to the company's goals.

I've successfully deployed this throughout my career:

Find what job is worth doing and put the right person on the job.

That can mean finding someone internally, hiring full-time, or paying a consultant.

Then, ensure they understand what needs to be done and expect them to deliver high-quality service.

Some people limit themselves to the knowledge they have and the knowledge they can acquire.

Other people delegate.

Who makes more impact?

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: Feelings are good, but metrics are better
item.description:
How do you ensure that your decisions and actions have a positive effect?

You need some metrics in place that are relevant to your business.

That's hard to get right. If you measure the wrong things, you'll optimize the wrong parts.

There's another problem. Plenty of metrics will lag behind your changes, so it may be difficult to attribute a result to your actions.

My suggestion here is to experiment and iterate.

But you have to start somewhere.

There are two ways to measure:
- Internal to the team
- Customer impact

One metric internal to the team could be how long it takes from the moment you start to work on a feature or a bug until it's deployed.

Uptime, new signups, churn, and bug report frequency could measure customer impact.

The point is to become outcome-driven and choose initiatives strategically based on facts, not feelings.

P.S. What metrics are you already tracking?

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: Don't paper your juniors
item.description:
Do athletes get better by not exerting themselves?

No.

It's deliberate, controlled stress that makes you stronger.

It's the same when you want to teach someone.

Give them only easy tasks, and they will never learn.

You need to stress them out.

But there are two kinds of stress.

Good stress, with enough recovery and motivation, makes them stronger.

Bad stress brings them down and makes them quit.

How do you cause good stress?

Give them a difficult challenge worth solving.

How do you cause bad stress?

Push them hard without empathy on a task they don't care about.

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: The danger of hybrid-remote work
item.description:
I'm in Croatia with my family, and this is not how my office looks like:

It's what my evenings look like.

I'm writing this email from a table in our apartment with dodgy wifi after the kids are asleep.

Here's the thing about working remotely (in a team).

It's easier to do when everyone's remote.

You'll approach collaboration differently when you can't meet anyone in the office.

You'll set up systems and processes.

You'll document more.

You won't spend time in useless sync meetings because you'll have to find a way to keep up with what everyone else is doing.

When you go fully remote, you can't even count on people being in the same timezone.

Or continent.

The mistake I see is companies adopting a hybrid approach, with some people going to the office (some of the time) while others are always remote.

That can easily create communication islands where the remote workers feel isolated and uninformed.

It's not just that you miss out on the water cooler conversations.

It's that most of what's going on and is important goes below your radar if you're amongst the people outside the office.

My advice if you're in this situation:

Force a 6-month fully remote regime.
Find what breaks.
Fix it.

Then, reintroduce hybrid mode while keeping the practices that kept your company going forward doing fully remote.

P.S. Keep watering the office plants; it's nice to have a work base. ;)

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: Do the right thing, wait to get fired
item.description:
As an engineering leader, you may be faced with an unethical choice.

Perhaps you get asked to start collecting your users' information without their consent?

Tweak the numbers a bit before an important investment meeting?

Implement dark patterns in your product?

Downplay a security vulnerability?

Covertly monitor your employees?

It's not always easy to figure out what is illegal.

But it's much easier to feel what is unethical.

If it feels wrong, it probably is wrong.

You have a choice.

Do the right thing and wait to get fired.

They may take you up on it (rarely), but that's just a signal to find a place where you won't be asked to do dodgy stuff.

Best regards,

Taj

​

item.title: Product, People, Purpose
item.description:
Engineering leadership is a triangle.

It's more about people and less about technology.

But it's not just management.

It's also about the product itself and the people who use it.

Here's the thing ...

If you want to do well,

be curious about what the users need and want,

find out how that helps the business grow,

and develop the tech that's needed.

Of course, you'll have dedicated roles in a company for each specializing in those.

But ... if you, as the engineering lead, don't have an intimate understanding of the users, the product, and the business, you are flying blind.

Being good at technology is not the end goal; it's the baseline.

How you apply that tech to solve problems is what drives results.

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: Why software complexity persists
item.description:
I was visiting Nin in Croatia today. It is one of the oldest towns in the Eastern Adriatic, having developed over 3000 years ago.

A lot changed in that time, but plenty stayed the same. We walked around and enjoyed a good meal.

I imagine this has not changed.

What about software?

Brooks' Law still holds: adding more people to a late project makes it later. Modern tools like Slack and GitHub simplify things but don't solve the fundamental problems of synchronizing a team.

Software is still complex, and it's arguably becoming more complex. We've just built better tools to handle the increased complexity brought by cloud architectures, microservices, or apps.

But we haven't solved the fundamental issues that make software development hard.

The limitation is still people.

A software project's success depends on team dynamics, individuals, communication gaps, leadership, decision-making...

We haven't found ways around these issues. Agile methodologies were an attempt to do so, but they failed spectacularly and mostly brought a different flavor of the good 'ol' waterfall.

Since I entered the industry as an amateur 20 years ago, the cognitive load on a developer only increased.

The number of tools, frameworks, libraries, procedures, languages, and architectures you need to know now is paralyzing. I don't envy juniors who didn't grow up with the technology but are thrown into the water to swim.

We've gone full circle with server-side rendering through SPAs and back to server-side.

And now, a new frontier is opening with AI.

It's too soon to judge whether it's actually going to make our jobs easier. Sure, some tricks are impressive, but I've still found them lacking for serious projects.

I wonder if, by adopting AI, we'll increase the complexity again and develop better toolings around it without actually addressing the things that make development hard.

People.

What do you think?

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: ⏱️ from blank to production
item.description:
How long does it take to go from a clean machine to your dev environment being set up?

If it's more than:

git clone [repo]
docker-compose up

It's probably too complicated.

Once you have everything set up, it's easy to forget how complex it was to assemble.

If you want a benchmark, onboard a new engineer.

How quickly can they submit a patch?

How quickly can they deploy it to production?

Same week?
Same day?
Same hour?

Faster makes it smoother. You'll get happier, more productive devs as a result.

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: Find people who raise the bar
item.description:
Recently, I’ve seen increasimg number of job ads that seek to fill a quota.

Hire for attitude and ability.

But most of all, hire people who raise the bar.

Even if it takes longer.

There’s no better way to destroy a company than through bad hires.

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: 75 days
item.description:
That's how many working days are left until the New Year.

It's the final sprint.

That's ~100 focused work sessions + the daily multitasking.

After freelancing for two years, I'm at a crossroads. While the autonomy is great, it's not paying the bills.

I'm cautiously exploring full-time opportunities that offer:

  • A senior tech leadership role (CTO, VPE, Director)
  • Autonomy in how I work
  • Opportunity to shape the tech strategy and mentor teams

My strengths remain:

  • Aligning tech with business goals
  • Mentoring tech leaders and teams
  • Optimizing development processes, developer experience, and CI/CD

What does that mean for you?

Very little. It's a different way to trade my expertise for money, one that offers more stability and less time spent on marketing, sales, legal, and proposals.

It would be nice to focus more on making a massive difference on a single project for a longer period of time.

I'm still committed to my daily email and sharing what I know and learn through my newsletter, LinkedIn, and YouTube.

Best regards,

Taj

P.S. Write to me if you know of a company that needs my particular set of skills. I'm looking for a product/service that makes a positive change in the world—hard no on ads, crypto, or gambling. Though I'm not against AI, I'll deduct -3 points every time the promo materials mention "AI" as a core feature. 🤷‍♂️

item.title: It's all about perception
item.description:
Back in 2011, I entered a student project competition. As a five-person team, we had to devise, design, and build a software project.

Naturally, we tried to build a game. Let's do something like the legendary Transport Tycoon but in a browser. Multiplayer. Real-time.

Ambitious? Yes.

Doable? Kinda.

It was a time when browser sockets and node.js were becoming hot.

After a few months of experimenting, we realized we wouldn't meet the deadline.

We had a shitty game. It was not fun to play. Lots of work left.

But it ran, and the tech behind it was cool—multiplayer in a browser.

So, we decided to pivot from our bad game being the product to:

Yes, the game is bad, but it's just a demo of what this amazing piece of technology can do. Here's the framework that runs it.

We won that competition.

Sometimes, all you need to do is to tell a better story.

It's a lesson I employed often since then.

The code is the code. A feature is a feature.

How you present it to your team, the board, the CTO, and your clients matters more than you think.

Find out what story you need to tell to get the result that you want.

Best regards,

Taj

P.S. Here's what my "game" looked like over 13 years ago when I still had plenty of hair, a youthful passion, and just a few seeds of wisdom. 👇🏻

The sharp-eyed may have noticed we pivoted from trains to tanks for the demo game. The gameplay was supposed to be very similar to Into the Breach (Subset Games, 2018). But it never went beyond a tech demo.

item.title: Software development is messy
item.description:
You have an idea for a product.

You design the features.

You build it.

That's the illusion.

The actual process is way messier.

There are two ways to deal with it.

You either embrace that it's going to be a mess, that the first version will suck and that you probably don't know more than you do know.

In this case, you'll optimize for learning.

You'll ship early and often.

You'll gather user feedback.

And you'll iterate and improve.

Or...

You pretend that you can get it right on the first try.

That a long planning phase can offset a lack of honest feedback.

And risk launching the product in front of the users only to find that no one cares.

The thing is ...

When I pitch it like this, you'll think it would be stupid to choose option 2.

But I've seen it repeatedly: People are convinced that just thinking through it for a long time gives them the necessary answers.

They build in isolation for months (years), adding hypothetical features.

Then, when they ship the product, after pouring in money, time, and sweat... and no one cares about the product.

Why is that?

Unrealistic expectations about software development.

The cure is to have your ideas challenged early and often, preferably by your users.

The worst thing you can do is to build in isolation.

Best regards,

Taj Pelc

item.title: ✋ STOP: High fidelity prototyping
item.description:
Building a SaaS is like cooking without a recipe. You know the best cooking principles, ratios, and techniques.

But you don't know the ingredients and how to prepare them.

It's usually even worse.

Perhaps you don't even know who's eating or whether you're making a dessert or cooking the main dish.

You may even try all three and decide to pivot to a burger joint.

Here's how I approach this.

You need to answer the questions:

  • Who is it for?
  • What problem does it solve for them?
  • How does it solve that problem?
  • Would they pay for it?

Somewhere in there, you'll need to build some software to test that hypothesis.

I think of it in terms of price/performance.

Production-grade software is a high investment, so you'll want to answer most questions before you commit by using cheaper methods.

User interviews, wireframes, and prototypes are your friends.

Those sets you up for a good swing at it.

The actual physical product in the hands of the users is the real test.

I'm not saying to do it in a waterfall style.

The goal is to learn fast and adapt fast.

But in the early stages, you learn fastest by avoiding building full products until you've exhausted other options.

That doesn't mean not to code.

It means to code strategically.

You have limited resources. Use them for maximal impact.

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: Complexity over time
item.description:
I had parked my car and was unloading stuff from the back seat when a driver decided to shave his mirror clean off using my door as a razor.

My door bent upwards a bit, but I channeled my anger at it and bent it back into shape, so it closed again properly.

I took the guy across the street to a bar to fill out the European accident report.

If you've never had the pleasure of filling that blue and yellow piece of paper, consider yourself lucky.

It records all info about both vehicles, insurance, drivers, the situation and what happened. With a nice sketch.

On Monday, I get an SMS from my insurance company to provide more details.

An automated wizard that asked for information.

The thing is ...

I had to type in the same answers that have already been submitted via the accident report.

And that happens to often when I see processes digitalized.

The process does not become easier, it becomes more complicated.

Suddenly, you need a phone, a laptop and 30 minutes of your time, wondering what to put in, instead of spending 5 minutes at a counter.

When you're digitalizing a manual process, it's tempting to add steps, because it's easy.

The real beauty of automation is to simplify.

Why not just scan the report, pre-fill all the info, attach the photos and leave an empty field for additional clarification?

It could have been 3 steps instead of 20.

Design it like Dieter Rams. Less, but better.

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: Getting clients is tough work
item.description:
Starting as a freelancer is romantic.

It feels great.

When I got started, I bought my pelc.cc domain first, set up an email account, put together a quick presentation site, and declared on LinkedIn that I was indeed available for contract work.

And then you know what happened?

...

..,.

Absolutely nothing.

Crickets. 🦗🦗

In my mind, I had a build-it attitude, and they will come.

It's funny because I would not build a SaaS like that, but I guess the cobblers' kids ain't got no shoes.

Here's what I'd do differently if I started again.

Find out what problem you want to solve for whom.

Pick one.

Find out if they think this is a problem worth solving.

Find how to solve that problem your way.

Find out how to market that solution so that your potential customers take notice and reach out.

Find out what you're willing to guarantee.

Find out how to differentiate yourself from the competition (what is your competition?).

For a start ...

Then there's the optimizations ... when you're getting enough clients, how do you optimize delivery.

How do you offer support once the project is over so that you can build recurring revenue and not always have to fish for the next client?

These are some of the questions I'm working through now.

But I wish that I'd apply what I already know about building products to my own service business.

At the end of the day, we're all building products, even if the product itself is us.

Best regards,

Taj Pelc

item.title: The problem of the CTO role evolution
item.description:
When I tell people what I do, I get this a lot:

Oh man, our CTO is not up to the tasks, projects are late, we are slow and the CEO is slowly recognising it's a problem.

That's a bad situation to be in, but it's also quite normal in an early stage startup that grows past a few engineers.

Early stage:

The CTO is the only tech person, prototyping.

MVP stage:

The CTO has a small team, but is still very much an individual contributor, plus handling all the IT and administrative things like buying computers and setting up access.

Growth stage:

Things start showing cracks. Progress stalls.

Let's unpack ...

Most startups grow way faster than the initial leadership team is able to keep up.

It takes many years to learn the skills to go from an individual contributor to an engineering manager.

It takes even longer to learn strategic thinking and to adopt a business-first mindset.

And that's okay.

But you need to have the uncomfortable conversation when cracks start to show and that's much easier if you've already talked about a plan on how to evolve the business.

Your options as the CEO are to hire a coach for your CTO, or have them step down and bring in someone strategic.

Coaching only works if the current CTO has an ambition to be a strategic lead. But not everyone wants that.

Stepping down is underrated.

Why not keep the salary, the shares and keep doing your best work, while someone else takes over talking to the board, interviewing, planning and tech strategy?

I've seen companies struggle because the CTO was one of the co-founders and the other founders didn't wanna have the hard talk.

They eventually hire a more experienced technical leader to take over, give him a Head of Tech title or similar and make the CTO report to them.

That's just silly.

But I've also seen founders who hired their replacement as soon as they could, so they could focus on growing the company and not working in the tech team.

There's not just one way to get it right, but ignoring the problems is a sure way to run into trouble.

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: Feel good content
item.description:
Software development has two sides.

The "it's just a button how hard can it be" illusion.

And what it actually looks like.

I admit that fewer people would probably want to "make an app" if they knew how much effort goes into it.

There are many traps that you need to avoid.

Like picking the wrong stack, hiring too early, not validating your features in front of the users, and more.

I write about those traps so that you can avoid them.

Let's face it, most development teams are not that fun to be on and it's easy to burn out.

But some are fucking amazing.

If you're building something you care about with people who are just as passionate as you and making real progress, it feels fantastic.

I want to enable more tech teams to achieve that.

I'll keep writing about the traps to avoid and what to do instead, so that you can grow and lead an amazing tech team.

The thing is ...

It's not feel-good content, because doing that is not easy.

It's hard and I feel it would be unfair to you to tell you it's not.

But plenty of things that are worth doing are hard.

Feel good about your strength and courage to go through a difficult process instead. 💪

Best regards,

Taj

item.title: How I think about OKRs
item.description:
OKRs* are so misunderstood that most companies that try to adopt them badly would be better off without them.

Here's a story I've seen way too often.

Things go poorly.
Top brass decides to roll out OKRs.
They create way too many top-level OKRs.
Everyone scrambles to create their own which feeds into that.
Suddenly you've got a million initiatives that dilute what little focus you had.

Why?

Because they are treated as a band-aid solution to a problem, not a tool to be deployed strategically.

If I'm asked to implement them in a tech team, here's my thought process.

OKRs are about outcomes.

They need to be relevant to the business, ambitious, and impactful.

Carefully selected.

Only a few.

Each one will open a new front. I don't want to dilute focus so that "we have OKRs".

They are a tool.

They help us focus, align the team, and measure progress against a goal.

Let's say I have an objective to grow the revenue by 30% in Q1. I identify the bottlenecks and I might define a key result to be:

Boost the percentage of new users who complete the onboarding process from 55% to 80% by the end of Q1.

Do you know what you might attempt to get that number up?

I bet you do.

What if I define it like this:

Redesign the onboarding process by the end of Q1.

You have no idea what to do.

What makes it bad?

No outcome. It's just a task.

No metrics. What will we know how much better it is?

No impact. What does this redesign hope to achieve?

No scope. Redesign can be a paint job a complete rebuild.

No results. It's going to be launched in Q1, then what?

So, what's the solution?

Look at everything that makes it bad and do the opposite.

Best regards,

Taj

*OKR = Objective and Key Results

item.title: Why generalists make great tech leaders
item.description:
Was Steve Jobs the best at writing code for the 1984 Macintosh?

No. It was his vision, leadership, team building, demanding excellence, and inspiring the team that revolutionized personal computing.

When I take on a strategic tech leadership position, I don't come there to be the best at writing backend code or designing software architecture.

In fact, realizing I'm the most skilled in these areas shows that my team needs to develop significantly to reach high performance.

As the tech lead, I focus on business goals, aligning the tech strategy around them.

It's much easier when I have people on the team who are better at the hands-on tasks than I am.

You don't need the best engineer to be a tech lead. Instead, you need to be able to see the big picture, think strategically, and translate business requirements.

My job is to find the right goal; my team's job is to find the right solution. If I've done a good job with them, I only need to paint the right targets.

P.S. I'm not saying you shouldn't be technical— you need to hold your own. But being a generalist in this case is a plus.

P.P.S. What qualities do you think are the most important for tech leadership? How important are technical skills?

Yours,

Taj

item.title: When business and tech fall out of sync
item.description:
Some people are really into technology. They're always interested in the latest framework, a new language, or a new cloud service.

Don't get me wrong, I love experimenting with new stuff too.

But in business, it's all about impact.

My alarm bells would go off if we were doing high-fidelity designs before technical scoping.

Sometimes, I was asked to plan the technical implementation of a feature before I knew what problem we were solving with it.

Things feel off when business and tech are not aligned.

The tech team should work on projects that bring value to the business. If there's a divide between the business objectives and the tech team's work, you can see it. Feel it.

The product team adds some features to the backlog without knowing what it takes to build them.

The tech team is busy rewriting a subsystem to microservices that will never return the investment.

Marketing is preparing a campaign without a tracking pixel to a landing page that won't handle the load.

It's the wild west. Everyone stands alone.

Everything is so damn hard. Every initiative is met with resistance, even the good ones.

There's a general atmosphere of gloom and futility.

Leave it be, and the company goes into a downward spiral.

Turning it around is possible with a few solid initiatives, a different mindset, and buy-in from the senior leadership.

Having someone show up with a fresh perspective to point at your blind spots helps a ton.

I'll break down my turnaround strategy in tomorrow's email.

Yours,

Taj

P.S. Ever worked in such an environment?

item.title: Market yourself
item.description:
When I'm stuck on a problem, my instinct is to push through it.

But sometimes, the solution is not to push through.

It's to take a break.

I've done my fair share of all-nighters to deliver some code that didn't work the next morning.

As I get older and that youthful fire fades, my priorities have shifted.

It's about what I can sustain long-term while starting a family.

The hardest part about being on your own is putting in the work with delayed feedback.

You need to believe that what you're working on is valuable to someone and keep giving.

So, for everyone who's in the same boat, I hear you.

The market is tough.

The competition is fierce.

But you have a lot of experience that someone might need right now.

The only question is, how do they find you?

Learn to market yourself. It's a skill worth developing whether you're looking for a job, starting a side hustle, or going freelance.

Yours,

Taj

P.S. I promised the turnaround yesterday, but the ideas are bigger than an email. Keep your eyes open for something better.

item.title: AI is not replacing programmers yet
item.description:
Using AI makes me faster (in some areas). Let's talk about writing code.

These days I use ChatGPT and Claude. I'll explain how in a bit, but let's first address GitHub Copilot.

I've found it to be nearly useless. The autocomplete feature gets things right just occasionally and is mostly a distraction. The ability to talk to it and ask it for code doesn't work as well as asking ChatGPT 4-o directly.

The way I use AI now is that I give it a few files, craft a good prompt, and get a decent answer. I then tweak that back and forth between the editor and the LLM interface.

The process is a bit clunky, but the results are good.

For me, it works best when describing how I want the UI to look and behave and generating HTML + CSS (+ JS). That allows me to rapidly prototype.

It can also do API requests, boilerplate, and GitHub Actions decently.

There's still a lot of work to make it production-ready.

Am I faster? Yes.

Can you go from a prompt to a production-ready app without knowing how to code in 2h? Hell no.

The main thing LLMs lack is deep reasoning abilities and a big enough context window.

The AI companies are working on both, but progress is slow. ChatGPT o1-preview is a bit better at reasoning and coding, but not magical.

Everyone is waiting for what the next generation will bring.

So no, AI is not replacing developer jobs yet, but it's making us faster (at some things).

That's why solution-based pricing is an even bigger advantage than before.

If AI makes you faster and you bill by the hour you'll be losing money.

The way to earn money is to solve big problems, faster and price the value of the solution, not the work that went into producing it.

Yours,

Taj

item.title: Untapped tech team potential
item.description:
Tech is at the end of the funnel, and that's a tough pill to swallow for those of us who live and breathe it.

You can have the best stack, the cleanest code, full-test coverage, automated deployments, and a dev experience so smooth that it makes new joiners cry.

But unless you've found a problem worth solving and developed the right solution, you won't get far.

Let's say you've even got killer features, but your offer sucks.

Perhaps onboarding is so convoluted that most give up before getting the benefits.

Perhaps everything works, but no one knows about it?

The point is that by the time you get to a technical solution, a lot has to click into place for it to matter.

What we can do from the tech team is get involved sooner to give better ideas, estimates, and prototypes.

At the end of the day, it's not product vs tech. Marketing vs sales.

It's the company trying to serve customers and turn a profit.

If you want to add value, find out what the company needs and how the tech team can support those goals.

You probably have more untapped potential in the tech team than you know.

Don't let them wait around for Jira tickets.

Yours,

Taj

item.title: What you measure gets improved
item.description:
Are you currently tracking any metrics in the engineering team?

Beyond the technical ones like uptime/downtime, latency, error rates and infrastructure costs.

Feature release frequency?

Security incidents?

Bug fix time?

Revenue?

CLTV?

NPS?

MRR?

The thing is ...

As engineers we love to focus on the operational metrics like uptime, database load and infrastructure costs.

But if you want engineering to contribute to business goals, then engineering should track those as well.

There's too many choices of what you can measure, so use this as the guideline:

If nothing will change in your behaviour if a metric goes up or down, then it's probably not worth tracking it.

Focus on what you can influence.

Btw, there's two types of metrics. The inputs (actions taken to achieve a goal) and outputs (results of those actions).

But that's a story for another day.

Yours,

Taj

item.title: Get engineers talking to customers
item.description:
The best tech strategy is user-centric. At the end of the day, who keeps the lights on?

Your customers.

And the way to grow the business and increase profit is to provide more value.

How?

Experience what a user of your app goes through.

Find out where the rough edges are.

Find out where they drop off.

Find out what they need.

Two quick ways that can be easily implemented.

  1. Put developers on customer support issues. Once they see the same issue 5 times, there's no chance a patch ain't rolling out tomorrow.
  2. Team up with the product team and do customer interviews.

But if I ask the users what they want, they'll ask for a faster horse!

Dismissing user feedback is the easy way out.

The truth is, you want to take it with a grain of salt and find out trends in your target audience.

And once you do that, finding out what to work on next will make a lot more sense than trying to outsmart the people that you serve in isolation.

Yours,

Taj

item.title: Feeling like a junior
item.description:
Feeling like a junior never really goes away.

With 20+ years of code experience, banging out a feature is routine.

But making a team plan for the next year, identifying skill gaps and finding solutions? Much harder, unless you've done it for a while too.

The truth is, you're always going feel like a junior in some area of your career—and't thats normal.

Embrace it.

Use the methods that have worked for you in the past to develop those new skills.

It's not you that's the problem. It's just a skill that you lack.

And skills can be learned.

Yours,

Taj

item.title: Is a business coach enough?
item.description:
At the highest level, most companies are the same. Same departments, same challenges.

You get a company to grow by addressing the blockers, often a combination of strategy and leadership.

How do you decide whether you need a business or technical leadership coach?

There's a significant overlap in responsibilities.

You get a business coach if the problems are predominantly related to people and processes. Perhaps the organizational structure, communication, or leadership skills must be improved.

However, a technical leadership coach may be better if a solution requires domain expertise, such as aligning tech initiatives with business strategy, improving the development process, managing tech debt, or evaluating tech team performance.

A fantastic tech product can only be built and maintained once you solve the company's leadership and organizational issues, so there will be an overlap between the two roles.

For example, imagine a tech company where the CTO constantly puts out fires in the codebase and neglects strategic planning. A business coach might advise on delegating tasks, managing time, and focusing on strategy.

However, they need to understand the technical depth to ensure that the development process can be improved and that the dev team should stop investing too much in a micro-service infrastructure too early.

Yours,

Taj

item.title: The mercy kill
item.description:
The fastest way to transform a team for high performance is to kick out the underperformers.

Is it possible to nurture underperformers into A-players? Absolutely.

Is it worth it? Probably not on your dime.

The thing is, when you want to move fast, you don't have the capacity for dead weight, and even less so for people who would actively pull you back.

A very successful project I've worked on started with a group of mixed skills and motivation. After a week, we got rid of the worst performer. We then gave two B-players non-critical tasks like documentation and testing.

We were left with a highly motivated and talented core that made massive progress in just a month while the rest played support roles.

We did more because fewer people were working on it.

It sounds counter-intuitive, but that's what you get when you remove dead weight and establish good support for the A-team.

Yours,

Taj

item.title: The cost of temptations
item.description:
Two ways to save money on development costs is to avoid premature optimisation and keep things simple.

The goal is typically not to have an elegant solution, it's to solve a problem for your customer.

Or perhaps find what customer to solve what problem for, depending on where in the journey you are.

Yet, this is still a struggle for me. I love having a custom built solution and tinker around.

The question I ask myself is:

How will doing that benefit [the goal]?

Building a nice sexy custom-built website for my business would be fun and is incredibly tempting, but if I just need to rapidly tweak my copy to test different offers a drag-and-drop website platform will do nicely.

Same goes for building software.

Don't distract yourself with things you would love to build that won't contribute massively to your goal.

Yours,

Taj

item.title: The winning combo, purpose and challenge
item.description:
If your bar is set low, you won't get much out of your employees. The most capable will leave in search of a better challenge and the average ones will settle for mediocrity.

But there's a second part to it.

As a leader, it's your role to show your team why their work is so important.

Humans want to work on something that has meaning to them.

So to get a winning team ...

Craft a compelling mission + Set a high bar = 🏆

Yours,

Taj

item.title: 3 short lessons I learned in tech leadership
item.description:
Knowing what to work on is more difficult than figuring out how to make it work.

Let's be real. Most projects I've been on have not been on the bleeding edge of computer science. Though I'm no stranger to using modern approaches, it's mostly been best practices and proven tech to solve a specific problem for a specific audience.

The tools are the same. What matters is how you apply them to the project at hand.

That said, figuring out what you should build is much more difficult.

When you know the what, the how is usually simple.

Business rarely understands tech. Tech usually ignores business.

Different incentives. Different skills. Different mindset.

To be a good engineering leader, you need to know both sides. And you need to be able to bring the business side closer to the developers.

The job of the software engineer is not to write code. It's to solve a problem for the customer. Yes, that often includes some code or automation.

But code is a means to an end, not an end in itself.

Siloses will form naturally because like attracts like. You need to actively design your organizational structure to achieve the desired effect.

Backend/Fronted and Product/Engineering are terrible split points, but plenty of companies do this.

I would not recommend it.

How you design your organization will have a massive impact on the way things are done.

Often, the best way to improve performance is not by implementing better processes.

It's by changing the organizational structure and communication. The rest will fit into place.

Yours,

Taj

item.title: Return to office, or else
item.description:
Remote work is under attack. Last week, my LinkedIn feed was just about Amazon calling for a return to office.

The post-pandemic bubble is starting to pop slowly.

But is remote work just a fad?

Companies calling for a return to the office believe that collaboration and innovation are better with physical presence.

They believe that being in the office can speed up the integration process.

Then there are productivity concerns.

It's notoriously difficult to measure intellectual productivity. But at least in the office, managers can see people "working" for their peace of mind.

The big tech companies have poured plenty of cash into physical office spaces; not using them doesn't justify the expense.

But what does it mean?

I believe remote work can be amazing if you support it properly.

Yes, it's more difficult to onboard, people may feel disconnected at times, and it's hard to collaborate if there's a weak process in place and not enough things are documented in the right way.

But if you get it right, I believe there are many pros to remote work, like increased productivity, no commute, and more comfort. It's especially good for families.

For me, the best mode is a hybrid remote. I like meeting people in person to better connect, then taking it remotely when I need to focus.

But the jury is still out on whether we can keep the remote momentum going or if we're coming full circle.

P.S. What do you think about return-to-office policies? Let me know.

Yours,

Taj

item.title: Security as an afterthought
item.description:
The Browser Company that makes the Arc browser had a massive security hole that potentially allowed anyone with a bit of skill to execute arbitrary code in your browser.

Massive oops. Here's what happened.

Arc enables you to write your own CSS/JS to customize and apply to a website through a feature called Boosts.

These Boosts are then synced between all your Arc installations using Firebase.

However, the Firebase ACL rules that Arc implemented allowed you to modify the creatorID that uniquely identifies you to that of another user, meaning you could upload any JS/CSS that you want to whomever you targeted and have it run on their side.

All you needed to know was your target's user ID which is not that hard to get.

They said that no one got hacked (according to their logs), and the hole was promptly patched, but it reveals a deeper issue.

The thing is...

I see too often that security is an afterthought. We need to start seeing it as a fundamental aspect of product quality instead.

Plenty of people jumped on Arc, not just for the tab management but also because "Arc is built from the ground up to be private and secure."

If security is a feature, you need to invest in security.

Independently audit the code and infrastructure.

Have an incident response strategy.

Penetration test it.

But perhaps the best remedy is to treat security as part of the culture you are building.

At the end of the day, security is not a one-time thing you do.

It's built layer after layer from the code, infrastructure, education, and processes.

The tricky part is that if you do a good job, no one will applaud you for the security incident that you didn't have, but that's the ultimate goal.

Yours,

Taj

item.title: Two problems of Engineering Management
item.description:
When you're a fresh developer, you get access to software engineering books, courses, and a senior who scrutinizes every line of code you write. You learn. You improve. Until someday, you get to pester some poor noob who doesn't know where to put his semicolons.

After a few years of pestering others, you get promoted to a team lead. Congratulations! 🎉

The problem is, no one gives you a brief on how to do that. There are no courses, no stack of books, and no seniors to pester you.

You're on your own.

Before you come at me with pitchforks, a select few companies have a structured training course for leadership. A rare few.

Being left alone means that many people in the company's mid-tier don't know how to lead — they only learn how to manage.

That's the first problem. Ineffective middle management can make any company feel like hell, especially if you have a very strategic top leadership who talks big vision.

But not every fresh engineering manager is as complacent. Some are passionate about their new position. They attend tech leadership courses, read books, and find mentors.

This leads me to the second problem: you're just important enough to be strategic but not enough to actually make a significant change.

So, if the top leadership doesn't care, it's hell for you anyway.

What can you do, sandwiched in the middle of the company?

You can learn to lead and improve the lives of those around you—your team, your peers, and the people.

Be a leader you wish you had and lead up the chain of command.

That's a tough job to do. In a big company, it's easiest to be a grunt. You do what you're told, don't complain, and get paid.

But if you step up that ladder, be prepared to be a shield and to lift others up. Tough, but ultimately rewarding work.

Yours,

Taj
